relationships.reasoning: A higher growth rate increases the daily growth of frimbulators.
relationships.polarityReasoning: An increase in growth rate causes an increase in growth, so the polarity is positive.

relationships.reasoning: A larger stock of frimbulators yields a larger absolute growth each day.
relationships.polarityReasoning: An increase in the frimbulator stock leads to an increase in growth, so the polarity is positive.

relationships.reasoning: Daily growth adds to the frimbulator stock.
relationships.polarityReasoning: An increase in growth increases the stock, so the polarity is positive.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I'm trying to do causal discovery, and extract every cause and effect relationship from the information I give you.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge: I start with one hundred whatajigs. Each year my collection of whatajigs increases by 5%. Each year my collection of whatajigs decreases by 300% of how ever many balack I currently have. I start with two hundred balacks. Each year my collection of balacks increases by 5% of how ever many whatajig I currently have. Each year my collection of balacks decreases by 3%.

supportingInfo.explanation: The model captures two interconnected stocks with flows that close into feedback loops. Whatajigs grow and are consumed by balacks; balacks grow on whatajigs and also decay naturally. Together these form a balancing loop: more whatajigs feed more balacks, which in turn consume whatajigs. Each stock also has its own self‐reinforcing (growth) or balancing (decay) loop.
supportingInfo.title: Coupled Whatajig–Balack Feedback

relationships.reasoning: The growth flow is calculated as 5% of the whatajig stock.
relationships.polarityReasoning: More whatajigs lead directly to more growth at a fixed rate.

relationships.reasoning: The loss flow is 300% of the balack stock.
relationships.polarityReasoning: More balacks cause more whatajigs to be lost.

relationships.reasoning: Growth adds to the whatajig stock.
relationships.polarityReasoning: An increase in inflow increases the stock.

relationships.reasoning: Loss subtracts from the whatajig stock.
relationships.polarityReasoning: An increase in outflow decreases the stock.

relationships.reasoning: Balack gain is driven by 5% of the whatajig stock.
relationships.polarityReasoning: More whatajigs yield a larger gain in balacks.

relationships.reasoning: Loss subtracts from the balack stock at 3%.
relationships.polarityReasoning: An increase in outflow decreases the stock.

relationships.reasoning: Gain adds to the balack stock.
relationships.polarityReasoning: An increase in inflow increases the stock.

relationships.reasoning: Loss is calculated as 3% of balack stock.
relationships.polarityReasoning: More balacks lead directly to more loss at a fixed rate.

additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge: I start with one hundred whatajigs. Each year my collection of whatajigs increases by 5%. Each year three whatajigs are removed from my collection of whatajigs. I start with two hundred balacks. Each year my collection of balacks increases by 5% of how ever many whatajig I currently have. Each year my collection of balacks decreases by 3%. I start with two hundred whoziewhats. Each year my collection of whoziewhats increases by 5% of how ever many balack I currently have. Each year my collection of whoziewhats decreases by 3%. I start with twelve funkados. Each year my collection of funkados increases by 5% of how ever many whoziewhat I currently have. Each year my collection of funkados decreases by 3% of how ever many maxabizer I currently have. I start with eighty-eight maxabizers. Each year my collection of maxabizers increases by 5% of how ever many funkado I currently have. Each year my collection of maxabizers decreases by 3% of how ever many whoziewhat I currently have.

supportingInfo.explanation: A single balancing feedback loop emerges between funkados and maxabizers: increases in funkados drive maxabizer growth, while higher maxabizers boost funkado removal, which in turn reduces funkados. No other closed loops are implied by the stated causal chains.
supportingInfo.title: Funkado–Maxabizer Balancing Loop

additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge: The less refluppers there are, the more exemintes there are. The more exemintes there are, the more ocs there are. The less ocs there are, the fewer proptimatires there are. The more proptimatires there are, the more priaries there are. The less priaries there are, the fewer houtals there are. The more houtals there are, the more povals there are. The less povals there are, the fewer refluppers there are.

supportingInfo.explanation: All seven variables form a single closed feedback loop. Refluppers affect Exemintes negatively, then propagate positive effects through Ocs, Proptimatires, Priaries, Houtals, and Povals, which in turn feed back positively on Refluppers. The product of polarities around the loop is negative, indicating a balancing feedback that will resist unbounded change and stabilize the system.
supportingInfo.title: Balancing Loop Among Seven Variables

additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge: The less frimbulators there are, the more whatajigs there are. The more whatajigs there are, the more balacks there are. The less balacks there are, the fewer frimbulators there are. The less balacks there are, the fewer whoziewhats there are. The more whoziewhats there are, the more funkados there are. The less funkados there are, the fewer maxabizers there are. The more maxabizers there are, the more marticatenes there are. The less marticatenes there are, the fewer balacks there are. The less marticatenes there are, the fewer refluppers there are. The more refluppers there are, the more exemintes there are. The less exemintes there are, the fewer ocs there are. The more ocs there are, the more proptimatires there are. The less proptimatires there are, the fewer priaries there are. The more priaries there are, the more marticatenes there are. The less outrances there are, the fewer illigents there are. The more illigents there are, the more houtals there are.

supportingInfo.explanation: The original text describes multiple causal chains that in fact form several closed feedback loops: 1) A negative loop among frimbulators, whatajigs and balacks. 2) A positive reinforcing loop linking balacks through whoziewhats, funkados, maxabizers and marticatenes back to balacks. 3) A second reinforcing loop from marticatenes through refluppers, exemintes, ocs, proptimatires and priaries back to marticatenes. 4) A reinforcing two-variable loop between priaries and houtals. 5) A balancing loop through houtals, povals, auspongs, dominitoxings, outrances, illigents back to houtals. No additional causal links were needed to close these loops, as all necessary relations were present in the background information.
supportingInfo.title: Feedback loops identified and closed

testParams.prompt: Using your knowledge of how the American Revolution started and the additional information I have given you, please give me a feedback-based explanation for how the American Revolution came about. Your response must include at least 10 variables.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how the American Revolution started. I'd like to know what caused hostilities to break out.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
The American Revolution was caused by a number of factors, including:
Taxation
The British imposed new taxes on the colonies to raise money, such as the Stamp Act of 1765, which taxed legal documents, newspapers, and playing cards. The colonists were angry because they had no representatives in Parliament.
The Boston Massacre
In 1770, British soldiers fired on a crowd of colonists in Boston, killing five people. The massacre intensified anti-British sentiment and became a propaganda tool for the colonists.
The Boston Tea Party
The Boston Tea Party was a major act of defiance against British rule. It showed that Americans would not tolerate tyranny and taxation.
The Intolerable Acts
The British government passed harsh laws that the colonists called the Intolerable Acts. One of the acts closed the port of Boston until the colonists paid for the tea they had ruined.
The French and Indian War
The British wanted the colonies to repay them for their defense during the French and Indian War (1754–63).
Colonial identity
The colonists developed a stronger sense of American identity

supportingInfo.explanation: We captured key dynamics by making colonial anger and revolutionary support the central stocks with inflows and outflows driven by taxation, repression, events, protests, propaganda, and concessions. A reinforcing loop forms as taxes and repressive acts raise anger, leading to more protests and thus more repression and anger (an escalation archetype). A balancing loop emerges when protests force British concessions that reduce taxation and anger (a success-to-the-successful archetype with a negative link). A second reinforcing loop closes through identity and propaganda: protests fuel propaganda, which strengthens shared identity, feeding back to greater support and more protests. This structure reflects how multiple feedbacks drove outbreak of hostilities.
supportingInfo.title: American Revolution Feedback Model

testParams.prompt: Using your knowledge of how road rage happens and the additional information I have given you, please give me a feedback-based explanation for how road rage incidents might change in the future. Your response must include at least 10 variables.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how road rage happens. I'd like to know what causes road rage in society.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
Road rage, defined as aggressive driving behavior caused by anger and frustration, can be triggered by various factors: 
Psychological Factors: 
Stress and Anxiety:
High stress levels can make drivers more irritable and prone to aggressive reactions. 
Personality Traits:
Individuals with impulsive, hostile, or competitive personalities may be more likely to engage in road rage. 
Frustration:
Feeling frustrated or blocked by other drivers can lead to anger and aggression. 
Situational Factors: 
Traffic Congestion:
Heavy traffic, delays, and stop-and-go conditions can increase stress and impatience. 
Perceived Provocations:
Being cut off, tailgated, or honked at can provoke anger and retaliatory behavior. 
Impatience:
Drivers who are running late or have a low tolerance for delays may become aggressive. 
Environmental Factors: 
Road Design:
Poor road design, such as narrow lanes or confusing intersections, can contribute to traffic congestion and frustration. 
Weather Conditions:
Adverse weather conditions, such as heavy rain or snow, can increase stress and make driving more challenging. 
Other Factors: 
Learned Behavior: Observing aggressive driving behavior from others can normalize it and increase the likelihood of engaging in road rage. 
Lack of Sleep: Fatigue can impair judgment and make drivers more susceptible to anger. 
Distracted Driving: Using a phone, texting, or eating while driving can increase the risk of accidents and provoke anger.

supportingInfo.explanation: Two reinforcing feedback loops dominate this model. Loop R1 links congestion to stress to frustration and then back through incidents to worsen congestion, illustrating how gridlock can self-intensify aggressive driving. Loop R2 shows incidents building a cumulative history that drives media coverage, which alongside rising aggressive norms and social acceptance, fuels more incidents and further norm adoption. An additional reinforcing loop between norms and acceptance ensures that once aggressive behavior spreads, it self-reinforces unless checked by norm decay. These archetypes mirror the “Growth and Underinvestment” archetype (congestion/stress loop) and “Success to the Successful” archetype (media-norms loop).
supportingInfo.title: Reinforcing Loops in Road Rage Dynamics

testParams.prompt: Using your knowledge of how the American Revolution started and the additional information I have given you, please give me a feedback-based explanation for how the American Revolution came about. Your response must include no more than 5 variables.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how the American Revolution started. I'd like to know what caused hostilities to break out.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
The American Revolution was caused by a number of factors, including:
Taxation
The British imposed new taxes on the colonies to raise money, such as the Stamp Act of 1765, which taxed legal documents, newspapers, and playing cards. The colonists were angry because they had no representatives in Parliament.
The Boston Massacre
In 1770, British soldiers fired on a crowd of colonists in Boston, killing five people. The massacre intensified anti-British sentiment and became a propaganda tool for the colonists.
The Boston Tea Party
The Boston Tea Party was a major act of defiance against British rule. It showed that Americans would not tolerate tyranny and taxation.
The Intolerable Acts
The British government passed harsh laws that the colonists called the Intolerable Acts. One of the acts closed the port of Boston until the colonists paid for the tea they had ruined.
The French and Indian War
The British wanted the colonies to repay them for their defense during the French and Indian War (1754–63).
Colonial identity
The colonists developed a stronger sense of American identity

supportingInfo.explanation: I introduced two reinforcing loops.  The first is a classic “escalation” loop: rising resentment drives hostilities, which provokes more British repression, in turn boosting resentment further (a Shifting the Burden archetype of escalating conflict).  The second loop captures how conflict deepens a shared identity: hostilities unify colonists, strengthening identity, which amplifies resentment and thus fuels more conflict (a reinforcing identity loop).  By adding the repression→resentment and hostilities→identity links, I closed both feedback loops and reflected the self-reinforcing dynamics that drove the Revolution.
supportingInfo.title: Reinforcing conflict and identity loops

testParams.prompt: Using your knowledge of how the American Revolution started and the additional information I have given you, please give me a feedback-based explanation for how the American Revolution came about. Your response must include at least 8 feedback loops.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how the American Revolution started. I'd like to know what caused hostilities to break out.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
The American Revolution was caused by a number of factors, including:
Taxation
The British imposed new taxes on the colonies to raise money, such as the Stamp Act of 1765, which taxed legal documents, newspapers, and playing cards. The colonists were angry because they had no representatives in Parliament.
The Boston Massacre
In 1770, British soldiers fired on a crowd of colonists in Boston, killing five people. The massacre intensified anti-British sentiment and became a propaganda tool for the colonists.
The Boston Tea Party
The Boston Tea Party was a major act of defiance against British rule. It showed that Americans would not tolerate tyranny and taxation.
The Intolerable Acts
The British government passed harsh laws that the colonists called the Intolerable Acts. One of the acts closed the port of Boston until the colonists paid for the tea they had ruined.
The French and Indian War
The British wanted the colonies to repay them for their defense during the French and Indian War (1754–63).
Colonial identity
The colonists developed a stronger sense of American identity

supportingInfo.explanation: This model captures multiple reinforcing and balancing feedbacks.  A key reinforcing loop forms as British_Harshness ↑ drives ABS_Growth ↑, building Anti_British_Sentiment ↑, which raises Colonial_Pressure ↑ and further increases British_Harshness.  A balancing loop emerges where growing Anti_British_Sentiment fuels Revolutionary_Sentiment, which builds Colonial_Unity ↑, reducing Political_Divisions ↓, thereby slowing ABS_Growth and moderating Anti_British_Sentiment.  Another balancing loop exists in unity dynamics: Political_Divisions ↑ → Unity_Erosion ↑ → Colonial_Unity ↓ → Political_Divisions ↑.  Sentiment moderation and revolutionary attrition provide two more balancing loops, each automatically checking high sentiment.  Tax_Burden’s link through Stamp Act, Tea Tax and Intolerable Acts adds a reinforcing path into British_Harshness.  Propaganda_Level driven by key events reinforces ABS_Growth, and Political_Divisions amplifies grievance-driven growth.  Overall, the model weaves at least eight closed loops—four reinforcing cycles magnifying British actions and colonial anger, and four balancing cycles through moderation, attrition, unity formation, and factional erosion.
supportingInfo.title: American Revolution Feedback Dynamics

Road rage, defined as aggressive driving behavior caused by anger and frustration, can be triggered by various factors: 
Psychological Factors: 
Stress and Anxiety:
High stress levels can make drivers more irritable and prone to aggressive reactions.

supportingInfo.explanation: We introduced stocks for social norms and cumulative incidents to capture long-term memory and learning effects. Flows for norm adoption and decay close reinforcing and balancing loops (Norm Reinforcement and Norm Decay B1). Linking incidents to congestion, stress, impatience, and provocations closes multiple reinforcing loops (R2–R5) where higher incidents fuel conditions that in turn raise incidents. Cumulative incidents feed both norm adoption (R6) and provocations (R8), creating long-term reinforcement. A well-known balancing decay of norms provides a self-limiting effect (B1). This structure uses archetypes of Reinforcing Growth and Balancing Limits to explain possible future trajectories of road rage.
supportingInfo.title: Reinforcing and Balancing Road Rage Loops

testParams.prompt: Using your knowledge of how the American Revolution started and the additional information I have given you, please give me a feedback-based explanation for how the American Revolution came about. Your response must include no more than 4 feedback loops.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how the American Revolution started. I'd like to know what caused hostilities to break out.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
The American Revolution was caused by a number of factors, including:
Taxation
The British imposed new taxes on the colonies to raise money, such as the Stamp Act of 1765, which taxed legal documents, newspapers, and playing cards. The colonists were angry because they had no representatives in Parliament.
The Boston Massacre
In 1770, British soldiers fired on a crowd of colonists in Boston, killing five people. The massacre intensified anti-British sentiment and became a propaganda tool for the colonists.
The Boston Tea Party
The Boston Tea Party was a major act of defiance against British rule. It showed that Americans would not tolerate tyranny and taxation.
The Intolerable Acts
The British government passed harsh laws that the colonists called the Intolerable Acts. One of the acts closed the port of Boston until the colonists paid for the tea they had ruined.
The French and Indian War
The British wanted the colonies to repay them for their defense during the French and Indian War (1754–63).
Colonial identity
The colonists developed a stronger sense of American identity

supportingInfo.explanation: Two reinforcing loops drive the turmoil. First, growing resentment fuels protests, provoking British crackdowns that deepen resentment (R1). Second, resentment builds a stronger colonial identity, which further amplifies protests and thus crackdowns and resentment (R2). This highlights the archetypal reinforcing cycle of oppression and resistance.
supportingInfo.title: Reinforcing Cycles of Colonial Resistance

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how road rage happens. I'd like to know what causes road rage in society.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
Road rage, defined as aggressive driving behavior caused by anger and frustration, can be triggered by various factors: 
Psychological Factors: 
Stress and Anxiety:
High stress levels can make drivers more irritable and prone to aggressive reactions. 
Personality Traits:
Individuals with impulsive, hostile, or competitive personalities may be more likely to engage in road rage. 
Frustration:
Feeling frustrated or blocked by other drivers can lead to anger and aggression. 
Situational Factors: 
Traffic Congestion:
Heavy traffic, delays, and stop-and-go conditions can increase stress and impatience. 
Perceived Provocations:
Being cut off, tailgated, or honked at can provoke anger and retaliatory behavior. 
Impatience:
Drivers who are running late or have a low tolerance for delays may become aggressive. 
Environmental Factors: 
Road Design:
Poor road design, such as narrow lanes or confusing intersections, can contribute to traffic congestion and frustration. 
Weather Conditions:
Adverse weather conditions, such as heavy rain or snow, can increase stress and make driving more challenging. 
Other Factors: 
Learned Behavior: Observing aggressive driving behavior from others can normalize it and increase the likelihood of engaging in road rage. 
Lack of Sleep: Fatigue can impair judgment and make drivers more susceptible to anger. 
Distracted Driving: Using a phone, texting, or eating while driving can increase the risk of accidents and provoke anger.

supportingInfo.explanation: Two reinforcing loops capture how aggression normalizes and how congestion fuels frustration. In the first loop, incidents accumulate, become observed, drive learned aggression, and spur further incidents. In the second, incidents cause accidents, leading to congestion, which raises frustration and thus incident rates. This closes the feedback chains implied by observation, learning, accidents, and congestion in the system.
supportingInfo.title: Road Rage Reinforcing Loops

The American Revolution was caused by a number of factors, including:
Taxation

In 1770, British soldiers fired on a crowd of colonists in Boston, killing five people. The massacre intensified anti-British sentiment and became a propaganda tool for the colonists.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how road rage happens. I'd like to know what causes road rage in society.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
Road rage, defined as aggressive driving behavior caused by anger and frustration, can be triggered by various factors: 
Psychological Factors: 
Stress and Anxiety:
High stress levels can make drivers more irritable and prone to aggressive reactions. 
Personality Traits:
Individuals with impulsive, hostile, or competitive personalities may be more likely to engage in road rage. 
Frustration:
Feeling frustrated or blocked by other drivers can lead to anger and aggression. 
Situational Factors: 
Traffic Congestion:
Heavy traffic, delays, and stop-and-go conditions can increase stress and impatience. 
Perceived Provocations:
Being cut off, tailgated, or honked at can provoke anger and retaliatory behavior. 
Impatience:
Drivers who are running late or have a low tolerance for delays may become aggressive. 
Environmental Factors: 
Road Design:
Poor road design, such as narrow lanes or confusing intersections, can contribute to traffic congestion and frustration. 
Weather Conditions:
Adverse weather conditions, such as heavy rain or snow, can increase stress and make driving more challenging. 
Other Factors: 
Learned Behavior: Observing aggressive driving behavior from others can normalize it and increase the likelihood of engaging in road rage. 
Lack of Sleep: Fatigue can impair judgment and make drivers more susceptible to anger.

supportingInfo.explanation: We built two reinforcing loops. The first loop links congestion to stress to incidents and back to congestion, capturing how gridlock fuels more aggressive events that further disrupt flow (akin to a Race to the Bottom archetype). The second loop captures social learning: incidents drive acquisition of aggressive norms that accumulate and generate yet more incidents (a reinforcing S‐curve of behavior diffusion). By embedding these loops in a minimal model, we show how congestion and social learning can jointly amplify road rage over time.
supportingInfo.title: Congestion and Social Learning Reinforcement

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how the American Revolution started. I'd like to know what caused hostilities to break out.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
The American Revolution was caused by a number of factors, including:
Taxation
The British imposed new taxes on the colonies to raise money, such as the Stamp Act of 1765, which taxed legal documents, newspapers, and playing cards. The colonists were angry because they had no representatives in Parliament.
The Boston Massacre
In 1770, British soldiers fired on a crowd of colonists in Boston, killing five people. The massacre intensified anti-British sentiment and became a propaganda tool for the colonists.
The Boston Tea Party
The Boston Tea Party was a major act of defiance against British rule. It showed that Americans would not tolerate tyranny and taxation.
The Intolerable Acts
The British government passed harsh laws that the colonists called the Intolerable Acts. One of the acts closed the port of Boston until the colonists paid for the tea they had ruined.
The French and Indian War
The British wanted the colonies to repay them for their defense during the French and Indian War (1754–63).
Colonial identity
The colonists developed a stronger sense of American identity

supportingInfo.explanation: We built four reinforcing loops of escalating grievances, protests, repression, and foreign aid (“escalation” archetype) and two balancing loops: one where hostilities force Britain to reduce taxes (a limits to growth archetype), and another where sentiment naturally decays if unrenewed.  Stocks accumulate anger, unity, hostilities, and military capacity.  Flows convert events and policies into gradual changes.  This captures how taxation, massacres, punitive acts, unity, and foreign support fed on each other, bounded only by concessions or natural fatigue.
supportingInfo.title: Colonial Grievance Escalation and Limits

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how road rage happens. I'd like to know what causes road rage in society.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
Road rage, defined as aggressive driving behavior caused by anger and frustration, can be triggered by various factors: 
Psychological Factors: 
Stress and Anxiety:
High stress levels can make drivers more irritable and prone to aggressive reactions. 
Personality Traits:
Individuals with impulsive, hostile, or competitive personalities may be more likely to engage in road rage. 
Frustration:
Feeling frustrated or blocked by other drivers can lead to anger and aggression. 
Situational Factors: 
Traffic Congestion:
Heavy traffic, delays, and stop-and-go conditions can increase stress and impatience. 
Perceived Provocations:
Being cut off, tailgated, or honked at can provoke anger and retaliatory behavior. 
Impatience:
Drivers who are running late or have a low tolerance for delays may become aggressive. 
Environmental Factors: 
Road Design:
Poor road design, such as narrow lanes or confusing intersections, can contribute to traffic congestion and frustration. 
Weather Conditions:
Adverse weather conditions, such as heavy rain or snow, can increase stress and make driving more challenging. 
Other Factors: 
Learned Behavior: Observing aggressive driving behavior from others can normalize it and increase the likelihood of engaging in road rage. 
Lack of Sleep: Fatigue can impair judgment and make drivers more susceptible to anger. 
Distracted Driving: Using a phone, texting, or eating while driving can increase the risk of accidents and provoke anger.

supportingInfo.explanation: This model captures both runaway escalation and brake-applied dynamics in road rage. Reinforcing loops show how incidents feed back through congestion, stress, learned aggression and social norms to drive still more aggression (escalation archetype). At the same time, balancing loops through enforcement and awareness counteract that rise (limits to growth archetype). Additional reinforcing pathways link distraction and fatigue back into incidents, closing feedback around multiple human and situational factors. By combining these R and B loops, the model reflects how road rage can spiral unchecked or be contained by policy and public response.
supportingInfo.title: Road Rage Feedback Loops Model

testParams.name: include a maximum number of feedback loops and a minimum number of variables for American Revolution
testParams.prompt: Using your knowledge of how the American Revolution started and the additional information I have given you, please give me a feedback-based explanation for how the American Revolution came about. Your response must include no more than 4 feedback loops and at least 5 variables.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how the American Revolution started. I'd like to know what caused hostilities to break out.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
The American Revolution was caused by a number of factors, including:
Taxation
The British imposed new taxes on the colonies to raise money, such as the Stamp Act of 1765, which taxed legal documents, newspapers, and playing cards. The colonists were angry because they had no representatives in Parliament.
The Boston Massacre
In 1770, British soldiers fired on a crowd of colonists in Boston, killing five people. The massacre intensified anti-British sentiment and became a propaganda tool for the colonists.
The Boston Tea Party
The Boston Tea Party was a major act of defiance against British rule. It showed that Americans would not tolerate tyranny and taxation.
The Intolerable Acts
The British government passed harsh laws that the colonists called the Intolerable Acts. One of the acts closed the port of Boston until the colonists paid for the tea they had ruined.
The French and Indian War
The British wanted the colonies to repay them for their defense during the French and Indian War (1754–63).
Colonial identity
The colonists developed a stronger sense of American identity

supportingInfo.explanation: We focused on two core reinforcing cycles: (1) taxation and repression fuel resentment, leading to more protest and heavier crackdown, which magnifies resentment again (Reinforcing loop). (2) rising resentment also builds colonial unity, which amplifies protest intensity and thus repression, feeding back to resentment. We balanced them with decay flows for resentment and unity, representing natural dissipation over time and preventing unbounded growth (Balancing loops).
supportingInfo.title: American Revolution Feedback Structure

testParams.name: include a maximum number of feedback loops and a minimum number of variables for Road Rage
testParams.prompt: Using your knowledge of how road rage happens and the additional information I have given you, please give me a feedback-based explanation for how road rage incidents might change in the future. Your response must include no more than 4 feedback loops and at least 5 variables.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how road rage happens. I'd like to know what causes road rage in society.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
Road rage, defined as aggressive driving behavior caused by anger and frustration, can be triggered by various factors: 
Psychological Factors: 
Stress and Anxiety:
High stress levels can make drivers more irritable and prone to aggressive reactions. 
Personality Traits:
Individuals with impulsive, hostile, or competitive personalities may be more likely to engage in road rage. 
Frustration:
Feeling frustrated or blocked by other drivers can lead to anger and aggression. 
Situational Factors: 
Traffic Congestion:
Heavy traffic, delays, and stop-and-go conditions can increase stress and impatience. 
Perceived Provocations:
Being cut off, tailgated, or honked at can provoke anger and retaliatory behavior. 
Impatience:
Drivers who are running late or have a low tolerance for delays may become aggressive. 
Environmental Factors: 
Road Design:
Poor road design, such as narrow lanes or confusing intersections, can contribute to traffic congestion and frustration. 
Weather Conditions:
Adverse weather conditions, such as heavy rain or snow, can increase stress and make driving more challenging. 
Other Factors: 
Learned Behavior: Observing aggressive driving behavior from others can normalize it and increase the likelihood of engaging in road rage. 
Lack of Sleep: Fatigue can impair judgment and make drivers more susceptible to anger. 
Distracted Driving: Using a phone, texting, or eating while driving can increase the risk of accidents and provoke anger.

supportingInfo.explanation: Three reinforcing loops and one balancing loop capture how incidents fuel more anger and norm building, which then drive further incidents. Loop R1 links incidents through increased provocations to anger and back to incidents. Loop R2 shows how incidents reinforce social norms of aggression that raise individual tendency and incident rates. Loop R3 captures how incidents worsen congestion, raising stress and anger. The balancing loop B1 lets anger naturally relax over time.
supportingInfo.title: Road Rage Feedback Loop Model

additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
The American Revolution was caused by a number of factors, including:
Taxation

supportingInfo.explanation: The model captures reinforcing dynamics where British fiscal and punitive pressures stir colonial grievances, breeding anti-British sentiment. Propaganda, unity, defiance, and repression interlock in several feedback chains, reflecting vicious cycles that drove hostilities upward.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how road rage happens. I'd like to know what causes road rage in society.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
Road rage, defined as aggressive driving behavior caused by anger and frustration, can be triggered by various factors: 
Psychological Factors: 
Stress and Anxiety:
High stress levels can make drivers more irritable and prone to aggressive reactions. 
Personality Traits:
Individuals with impulsive, hostile, or competitive personalities may be more likely to engage in road rage. 
Frustration:
Feeling frustrated or blocked by other drivers can lead to anger and aggression. 
Situational Factors: 
Traffic Congestion:
Heavy traffic, delays, and stop-and-go conditions can increase stress and impatience. 
Perceived Provocations:
Being cut off, tailgated, or honked at can provoke anger and retaliatory behavior. 
Impatience:
Drivers who are running late or have a low tolerance for delays may become aggressive. 
Environmental Factors: 
Road Design:
Poor road design, such as narrow lanes or confusing intersections, can contribute to traffic congestion and frustration. 
Weather Conditions:
Adverse weather conditions, such as heavy rain or snow, can increase stress and make driving more challenging. 
Other Factors: 
Learned Behavior: Observing aggressive driving behavior from others can normalize it and increase the likelihood of engaging in road rage. 
Lack of Sleep: Fatigue can impair judgment and make drivers more susceptible to anger. 
Distracted Driving: Using a phone, texting, or eating while driving can increase the risk of accidents and provoke anger.

supportingInfo.explanation: The model captures four reinforcing loops that amplify road rage and two balancing loops that temper incident growth. In reinforcing loop R1 (congestion), accidents from road rage increase traffic congestion and frustration, driving new incidents. Loop R2 (stress) shows how incidents raise driver stress, which further fuels incidents. Loop R3 (norms) describes how cumulative incidents normalize aggressive behavior, leading to higher incident rates. Loop R4 (sleep) links congestion-induced sleep deprivation to stress and subsequent incidents. Balancing loop B1 (media) has media coverage spur safety measure adoption, reducing incidents. Loop B2 (enforcement) uses law enforcement attention to raise perceived risk and deter aggressive driving. These dynamics reflect escalation and limit-to-growth archetypes, highlighting leverage points in design, policy, and public awareness.
supportingInfo.title: Road Rage Feedback Loop Dynamics

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how road rage happens. I'd like to know what causes road rage in society.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
Road rage, defined as aggressive driving behavior caused by anger and frustration, can be triggered by various factors: 
Psychological Factors: 
Stress and Anxiety:

Personality Traits:

supportingInfo.explanation: This model captures a reinforcing loop where higher traffic congestion raises driver stress, which increases accidents that further build congestion (R1). Two balancing loops regulate each stock: stress recovery dampens stress accumulation (B1), and congestion naturally dissipates over time (B2). Constants were chosen for simplicity to close the loops and illustrate how road rage dynamics can self-amplify but also self-limit.
supportingInfo.title: Road Rage Feedback Loop Structure

testParams.name: Extract a single stock with one flow
testParams.prompt: Please give me a model which includes all causal relationships in the background information.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I'm trying to do causal discovery, and extract every cause and effect relationship from the information I give you.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge: I start with twenty frimbulators. Each day my collection of frimbulators increases by 2%.

supportingInfo.explanation: The model captures a reinforcing feedback loop: as the frimbulator collection grows, the daily increase grows, which further increases the collection. This is a classic exponential growth archetype, where the stock and its growth rate reinforce each other through the flow. additionalParameters.problemStatement: I'm trying to do causal discovery, and extract every cause and effect relationship from the information I give you.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge: I start with one hundred whatajigs. Each year my collection of whatajigs increases by 5%. Each year three whatajigs are removed from my collection of whatajigs. I start with two hundred balacks. Each year my collection of balacks increases by 5% of how ever many whatajig I currently have. Each year my collection of balacks decreases by 3%. I start with two hundred whoziewhats. Each year my collection of whoziewhats increases by 5% of how ever many balack I currently have. Each year my collection of whoziewhats decreases by 3%. I start with twelve funkados. Each year my collection of funkados increases by 5% of how ever many whoziewhat I currently have. Each year my collection of funkados decreases by 3% of how ever many maxabizer I currently have. I start with eighty-eight maxabizers. Each year my collection of maxabizers increases by 5% of how ever many funkado I currently have. Each year my collection of maxabizers decreases by 3% of how ever many whoziewhat I currently have.

supportingInfo.explanation: This model forms a closed feedback loop across all five stocks: whatajig, balack, whoziewhat, funkado, and maxabizer. Each stock's inflow is based on the previous stock, and each outflow is based on itself or the next stock, creating a circular chain of causality. For example, whatajig affects balack, which affects whoziewhat, which affects funkado, which affects maxabizer, which in turn affects funkado's outflow. This closes the loop, as maxabizer's outflow is also affected by whoziewhat, which is earlier in the chain. This structure is a classic example of a closed reinforcing and balancing feedback loop, where each stock both influences and is influenced by others in a circular manner.
supportingInfo.title: Closed Feedback Loop Among Five Stocks

The less proptimatires there are, the fewer priaries there are. The more priaries there are, the more houtals there are. The less houtals there are, the fewer povals there are. The more povals there are, the more auspongs there are. The less auspongs there are, the fewer dominitoxings there are. The more dominitoxings there are, the more exemintes there are.

supportingInfo.explanation: The model forms a closed feedback loop: exemintes → ocs → proptimatires → priaries → houtals → povals → auspongs → dominitoxings → exemintes. Each variable is linked to the next by the causal relationships described, and the loop closes with dominitoxings increasing exemintes. The polarity of each relationship was carefully interpreted from the phrasing, with negative statements often indicating a positive correlation. This structure is a classic reinforcing loop, where changes propagate around the loop and can amplify over time.
supportingInfo.title: Closed reinforcing loop among all variables

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I'm trying to do causal discovery, and extract every cause and effect relationship from the information I give you.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge: The less frimbulators there are, the more whatajigs there are. The more whatajigs there are, the more balacks there are. The less balacks there are, the fewer frimbulators there are. The less balacks there are, the fewer whoziewhats there are. The more whoziewhats there are, the more funkados there are. The less funkados there are, the fewer maxabizers there are. The more maxabizers there are, the more marticatenes there are. The less marticatenes there are, the fewer balacks there are. The less marticatenes there are, the fewer refluppers there are. The more refluppers there are, the more exemintes there are. The less exemintes there are, the fewer ocs there are. The more ocs there are, the more proptimatires there are. The less proptimatires there are, the fewer priaries there are. The more priaries there are, the more marticatenes there are. The less priaries there are, the more houtals there are. The more houtals there are, the more priaries there are. The less houtals there are, the more povals there are. The more povals there are, the more auspongs there are. The less auspongs there are, the fewer dominitoxings there are. The more dominitoxings there are, the more outrances there are. The less outrances there are, the fewer illigents there are. The more illigents there are, the more houtals there are.

supportingInfo.explanation: This model contains multiple closed feedback loops, including a large reinforcing loop: frimbulators → whatajigs → balacks → frimbulators, and a second loop: priaries → marticatenes → balacks → frimbulators → whatajigs → balacks. There are also balancing loops involving houtals, povals, auspongs, dominitoxings, outrances, illigents, and back to houtals. All relationships are directly supported by the provided statements, and the loops are closed by following the chains of causality as described.
supportingInfo.title: Multiple Interlocking Feedback Loops Identified

testParams.name: include a minimum number of variables for American Revolution
testParams.prompt: Using your knowledge of how the American Revolution started and the additional information I have given you, please give me a feedback-based explanation for how the American Revolution came about. Your response must include at least 10 variables.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how the American Revolution started. I'd like to know what caused hostilities to break out.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
The American Revolution was caused by a number of factors, including:
Taxation
The British imposed new taxes on the colonies to raise money, such as the Stamp Act of 1765, which taxed legal documents, newspapers, and playing cards. The colonists were angry because they had no representatives in Parliament.
The Boston Massacre
In 1770, British soldiers fired on a crowd of colonists in Boston, killing five people. The massacre intensified anti-British sentiment and became a propaganda tool for the colonists.
The Boston Tea Party
The Boston Tea Party was a major act of defiance against British rule. It showed that Americans would not tolerate tyranny and taxation.
The Intolerable Acts
The British government passed harsh laws that the colonists called the Intolerable Acts. One of the acts closed the port of Boston until the colonists paid for the tea they had ruined.
The French and Indian War
The British wanted the colonies to repay them for their defense during the French and Indian War (1754–63).
Colonial identity
The colonists developed a stronger sense of American identity

supportingInfo.explanation: This model closes several feedback loops. The first is a reinforcing loop: higher colonial grievances increase colonial identity, which boosts propaganda effectiveness, amplifying the impact of events like the Boston Massacre and Tea Party, which further increase grievances. Another reinforcing loop is that higher grievances and identity increase hostility, which provokes a stronger British response (Intolerable Acts), which in turn increases grievances. There is also a balancing loop: higher British debt leads to more taxation, which increases grievances, but also repays debt, eventually reducing the pressure to tax. These feedbacks capture the escalation of tensions and the self-reinforcing nature of colonial resistance and British repression.
supportingInfo.title: Feedback Loops Escalate Colonial British Hostility

testParams.name: include a minimum number of variables for Road Rage
testParams.prompt: Using your knowledge of how road rage happens and the additional information I have given you, please give me a feedback-based explanation for how road rage incidents might change in the future. Your response must include at least 10 variables.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how road rage happens. I'd like to know what causes road rage in society.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
Road rage, defined as aggressive driving behavior caused by anger and frustration, can be triggered by various factors: 
Psychological Factors: 
Stress and Anxiety:
High stress levels can make drivers more irritable and prone to aggressive reactions. 
Personality Traits:
Individuals with impulsive, hostile, or competitive personalities may be more likely to engage in road rage. 
Frustration:
Feeling frustrated or blocked by other drivers can lead to anger and aggression. 
Situational Factors: 
Traffic Congestion:
Heavy traffic, delays, and stop-and-go conditions can increase stress and impatience. 
Perceived Provocations:
Being cut off, tailgated, or honked at can provoke anger and retaliatory behavior. 
Impatience:
Drivers who are running late or have a low tolerance for delays may become aggressive. 
Environmental Factors: 
Road Design:
Poor road design, such as narrow lanes or confusing intersections, can contribute to traffic congestion and frustration. 
Weather Conditions:
Adverse weather conditions, such as heavy rain or snow, can increase stress and make driving more challenging. 
Other Factors: 
Learned Behavior: Observing aggressive driving behavior from others can normalize it and increase the likelihood of engaging in road rage. 
Lack of Sleep: Fatigue can impair judgment and make drivers more susceptible to anger. 
Distracted Driving: Using a phone, texting, or eating while driving can increase the risk of accidents and provoke anger.

supportingInfo.explanation: This model closes two reinforcing feedback loops: (1) More road rage incidents increase perceived provocations and learned behavior, which in turn increase new incidents, creating a self-reinforcing cycle. (2) More incidents also increase the rate at which incidents are resolved, providing a balancing loop. The model incorporates psychological, situational, and environmental factors, and links them through causal relationships supported by research. The feedback structure highlights how road rage can escalate in society if not interrupted, but also how resolution processes can dampen the escalation.
supportingInfo.title: Feedback Loops in Road Rage Dynamics

testParams.prompt: Using your knowledge of how the American Revolution started and the additional information I have given you, please give me a feedback-based explanation for how the American Revolution came about. Your response must include no more than 5 variables.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how the American Revolution started. I'd like to know what caused hostilities to break out.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
The American Revolution was caused by a number of factors, including:
Taxation
The British imposed new taxes on the colonies to raise money, such as the Stamp Act of 1765, which taxed legal documents, newspapers, and playing cards. The colonists were angry because they had no representatives in Parliament.
The Boston Massacre
In 1770, British soldiers fired on a crowd of colonists in Boston, killing five people. The massacre intensified anti-British sentiment and became a propaganda tool for the colonists.
The Boston Tea Party
The Boston Tea Party was a major act of defiance against British rule. It showed that Americans would not tolerate tyranny and taxation.
The Intolerable Acts
The British government passed harsh laws that the colonists called the Intolerable Acts. One of the acts closed the port of Boston until the colonists paid for the tea they had ruined.
The French and Indian War
The British wanted the colonies to repay them for their defense during the French and Indian War (1754–63).
Colonial identity
The colonists developed a stronger sense of American identity

supportingInfo.explanation: This model closes a reinforcing feedback loop: as British policies and military actions increase, colonial grievances accumulate, which in turn strengthens colonial identity. A stronger identity provokes harsher British policies, further increasing grievances. This is a classic escalation (reinforcing) loop, often seen in conflict archetypes. The model also includes a balancing loop: as grievances rise, so does the rate of resolution, which can slow the accumulation. The interplay of these loops helps explain the escalation to open hostilities.
supportingInfo.title: Feedback Loops Driving American Revolution Escalation

supportingInfo.explanation: This model closes a reinforcing feedback loop: as road rage incidents increase, learned behavior rises, which further increases new road rage incidents. This is a classic positive feedback (reinforcing) loop, often seen in social contagion or normalization archetypes. The other variables (stress level, perceived provocations) act as drivers but do not themselves form additional loops within the five-variable limit. The model highlights how road rage can become self-reinforcing in society.

variables.name: new road rage incidents

variables.name: stress level
variables.equation: traffic congestion + lack of sleep + weather conditions

variables.name: perceived provocations
variables.documentation: Represents the frequency with which drivers perceive provocations from others, such as being cut off or tailgated. Influenced by traffic congestion and distracted driving. Chosen because perceived provocations are a direct trigger for road rage.

variables.name: learned behavior
variables.equation: base learned behavior + road rage incidents * 0.05
variables.documentation: Represents the degree to which aggressive driving is normalized and learned by observing others. Increases as road rage incidents increase, creating a reinforcing feedback loop. Chosen to capture the social learning aspect.

Taxation
The British imposed new taxes on the colonies to raise money, such as the Stamp Act of 1765, which taxed legal documents, newspapers, and playing cards. The colonists were angry because they had no representatives in Parliament.
The Boston Massacre
In 1770, British soldiers fired on a crowd of colonists in Boston, killing five people. The massacre intensified anti-British sentiment and became a propaganda tool for the colonists.
The Boston Tea Party
The Boston Tea Party was a major act of defiance against British rule. It showed that Americans would not tolerate tyranny and taxation.
The Intolerable Acts
The British government passed harsh laws that the colonists called the Intolerable Acts. One of the acts closed the port of Boston until the colonists paid for the tea they had ruined.
The French and Indian War
The British wanted the colonies to repay them for their defense during the French and Indian War (1754–63).
Colonial identity
The colonists developed a stronger sense of American identity

supportingInfo.explanation: This model closes multiple feedback loops by connecting colonial resentment, propaganda, anti-British sentiment, and hostilities. For example, greater resentment increases propaganda, which amplifies anti-British sentiment, which in turn increases resentment—a reinforcing loop. Hostility feeds back into propaganda and anti-British sentiment, further reinforcing the cycle. Economic hardship and loss of autonomy also feed into resentment, which then loops back through identity and sentiment. The model includes at least eight reinforcing feedback loops, capturing the self-reinforcing dynamics that escalated tensions and led to the outbreak of the American Revolution.
supportingInfo.title: Feedback Loops Escalating American Revolutionary Hostility

testParams.name: include a minimum number of feedback loops for Road Rage
testParams.prompt: Using your knowledge of how road rage happens and the additional information I have given you, please give me a feedback-based explanation for how road rage incidents might change in the future. Your response must include at least 8 feedback loops.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how road rage happens. I'd like to know what causes road rage in society.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
Road rage, defined as aggressive driving behavior caused by anger and frustration, can be triggered by various factors: 
Psychological Factors: 
Stress and Anxiety:
High stress levels can make drivers more irritable and prone to aggressive reactions. 
Personality Traits:
Individuals with impulsive, hostile, or competitive personalities may be more likely to engage in road rage. 
Frustration:
Feeling frustrated or blocked by other drivers can lead to anger and aggression. 
Situational Factors: 
Traffic Congestion:
Heavy traffic, delays, and stop-and-go conditions can increase stress and impatience. 
Perceived Provocations:
Being cut off, tailgated, or honked at can provoke anger and retaliatory behavior. 
Impatience:
Drivers who are running late or have a low tolerance for delays may become aggressive. 
Environmental Factors: 
Road Design:
Poor road design, such as narrow lanes or confusing intersections, can contribute to traffic congestion and frustration. 
Weather Conditions:
Adverse weather conditions, such as heavy rain or snow, can increase stress and make driving more challenging. 
Other Factors: 
Learned Behavior: Observing aggressive driving behavior from others can normalize it and increase the likelihood of engaging in road rage. 
Lack of Sleep: Fatigue can impair judgment and make drivers more susceptible to anger. 
Distracted Driving: Using a phone, texting, or eating while driving can increase the risk of accidents and provoke anger.

supportingInfo.explanation: This model closes multiple feedback loops by connecting road rage incidents to the psychological, situational, and behavioral factors that both cause and are caused by road rage. For example, more road rage incidents increase stress, frustration, impatience, congestion, provocations, learned behavior, fatigue, and distracted driving, all of which in turn increase the rate of new incidents. This creates reinforcing feedback loops (vicious cycles) where road rage can escalate. The model also includes balancing feedback through the resolution of incidents. The structure reflects archetypes such as 'Reinforcing Loops' (vicious cycles) and 'Escalation'. Eight distinct reinforcing loops are present: (1) Incidents → Stress → Incidents, (2) Incidents → Frustration → Incidents, (3) Incidents → Impatience → Incidents, (4) Incidents → Congestion → Stress/Frustration/Impatience → Incidents, (5) Incidents → Provocations → Frustration/Incidents, (6) Incidents → Learned Behavior → Incidents, (7) Incidents → Fatigue → Stress/Incidents, (8) Incidents → Distracted Driving → Provocations/Incidents. These loops show how road rage can self-perpetuate and intensify unless interrupted.
supportingInfo.title: Eight Feedback Loops Drive Road Rage Escalation

testParams.name: include a maximum number of feedback loops for American Revolution
testParams.prompt: Using your knowledge of how the American Revolution started and the additional information I have given you, please give me a feedback-based explanation for how the American Revolution came about. Your response must include no more than 4 feedback loops.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how the American Revolution started. I'd like to know what caused hostilities to break out.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
The American Revolution was caused by a number of factors, including:
Taxation
The British imposed new taxes on the colonies to raise money, such as the Stamp Act of 1765, which taxed legal documents, newspapers, and playing cards. The colonists were angry because they had no representatives in Parliament.
The Boston Massacre
In 1770, British soldiers fired on a crowd of colonists in Boston, killing five people. The massacre intensified anti-British sentiment and became a propaganda tool for the colonists.
The Boston Tea Party
The Boston Tea Party was a major act of defiance against British rule. It showed that Americans would not tolerate tyranny and taxation.
The Intolerable Acts
The British government passed harsh laws that the colonists called the Intolerable Acts. One of the acts closed the port of Boston until the colonists paid for the tea they had ruined.
The French and Indian War
The British wanted the colonies to repay them for their defense during the French and Indian War (1754–63).
Colonial identity
The colonists developed a stronger sense of American identity

supportingInfo.explanation: This model closes two key reinforcing feedback loops. First, as colonial resentment grows, it strengthens colonial identity, which in turn makes colonists more sensitive to British actions, further increasing resentment—a classic reinforcing loop (R1). Second, events like the Boston Massacre and Boston Tea Party feed into propaganda, which amplifies resentment, further fueling identity and thus more propaganda and resistance (R2). These loops capture the escalation dynamic that led to open hostilities. The model also includes direct effects of British policies and actions, but the feedback structure is what explains the self-reinforcing path to revolution.
supportingInfo.title: Feedback Loops Escalate Colonial Resentment Dynamics

testParams.name: include a maximum number of feedback loops for Road Rage
testParams.prompt: Using your knowledge of how road rage happens and the additional information I have given you, please give me a feedback-based explanation for how road rage incidents might change in the future. Your response must include no more than 4 feedback loops.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how road rage happens. I'd like to know what causes road rage in society.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
Road rage, defined as aggressive driving behavior caused by anger and frustration, can be triggered by various factors: 
Psychological Factors: 
Stress and Anxiety:
High stress levels can make drivers more irritable and prone to aggressive reactions. 
Personality Traits:
Individuals with impulsive, hostile, or competitive personalities may be more likely to engage in road rage. 
Frustration:
Feeling frustrated or blocked by other drivers can lead to anger and aggression. 
Situational Factors: 
Traffic Congestion:
Heavy traffic, delays, and stop-and-go conditions can increase stress and impatience. 
Perceived Provocations:
Being cut off, tailgated, or honked at can provoke anger and retaliatory behavior. 
Impatience:
Drivers who are running late or have a low tolerance for delays may become aggressive. 
Environmental Factors: 
Road Design:
Poor road design, such as narrow lanes or confusing intersections, can contribute to traffic congestion and frustration. 
Weather Conditions:
Adverse weather conditions, such as heavy rain or snow, can increase stress and make driving more challenging. 
Other Factors: 
Learned Behavior: Observing aggressive driving behavior from others can normalize it and increase the likelihood of engaging in road rage. 
Lack of Sleep: Fatigue can impair judgment and make drivers more susceptible to anger. 
Distracted Driving: Using a phone, texting, or eating while driving can increase the risk of accidents and provoke anger.

supportingInfo.explanation: This model identifies three reinforcing feedback loops: (1) More road rage incidents increase learned behavior, which further increases new incidents; (2) More incidents increase perceived provocations, which also drive new incidents; (3) Stress and impatience reinforce each other, as stress increases impatience, which then increases new incidents, feeding back into the system. There is also a balancing loop: as incidents accumulate, more are resolved, preventing runaway growth. These loops capture how road rage can escalate or stabilize over time, depending on the strength of reinforcing versus balancing effects.
supportingInfo.title: Feedback Loops Driving Road Rage Incidents

testParams.prompt: Using your knowledge of how the American Revolution started and the additional information I have given you, please give me a feedback-based explanation for how the American Revolution came about. Your response must include no more than 4 feedback loops and no more than 5 variables.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how the American Revolution started. I'd like to know what caused hostilities to break out.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
The American Revolution was caused by a number of factors, including:
Taxation
The British imposed new taxes on the colonies to raise money, such as the Stamp Act of 1765, which taxed legal documents, newspapers, and playing cards. The colonists were angry because they had no representatives in Parliament.
The Boston Massacre
In 1770, British soldiers fired on a crowd of colonists in Boston, killing five people. The massacre intensified anti-British sentiment and became a propaganda tool for the colonists.
The Boston Tea Party
The Boston Tea Party was a major act of defiance against British rule. It showed that Americans would not tolerate tyranny and taxation.
The Intolerable Acts
The British government passed harsh laws that the colonists called the Intolerable Acts. One of the acts closed the port of Boston until the colonists paid for the tea they had ruined.
The French and Indian War
The British wanted the colonies to repay them for their defense during the French and Indian War (1754–63).
Colonial identity
The colonists developed a stronger sense of American identity

supportingInfo.explanation: This model captures two reinforcing feedback loops and one balancing loop. The first reinforcing loop is: British pressures increase colonial grievances, which in turn prompt more British pressures—a classic escalation archetype. The second reinforcing loop is: as grievances rise, colonial identity strengthens, which increases anti-British sentiment, further accelerating grievance accumulation. The balancing loop is: as colonial identity grows, colonists become less willing to resolve grievances, slowing down the resolution process. These loops together explain how hostilities escalated toward revolution.
supportingInfo.title: Feedback Loops Driving American Revolution Escalation

testParams.prompt: Using your knowledge of how road rage happens and the additional information I have given you, please give me a feedback-based explanation for how road rage incidents might change in the future. Your response must include no more than 4 feedback loops and no more than 5 variables.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how road rage happens. I'd like to know what causes road rage in society.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
Road rage, defined as aggressive driving behavior caused by anger and frustration, can be triggered by various factors: 
Psychological Factors: 
Stress and Anxiety:
High stress levels can make drivers more irritable and prone to aggressive reactions. 
Personality Traits:
Individuals with impulsive, hostile, or competitive personalities may be more likely to engage in road rage. 
Frustration:
Feeling frustrated or blocked by other drivers can lead to anger and aggression. 
Situational Factors: 
Traffic Congestion:
Heavy traffic, delays, and stop-and-go conditions can increase stress and impatience. 
Perceived Provocations:
Being cut off, tailgated, or honked at can provoke anger and retaliatory behavior. 
Impatience:
Drivers who are running late or have a low tolerance for delays may become aggressive. 
Environmental Factors: 
Road Design:
Poor road design, such as narrow lanes or confusing intersections, can contribute to traffic congestion and frustration. 
Weather Conditions:
Adverse weather conditions, such as heavy rain or snow, can increase stress and make driving more challenging. 
Other Factors: 
Learned Behavior: Observing aggressive driving behavior from others can normalize it and increase the likelihood of engaging in road rage. 
Lack of Sleep: Fatigue can impair judgment and make drivers more susceptible to anger. 
Distracted Driving: Using a phone, texting, or eating while driving can increase the risk of accidents and provoke anger.

supportingInfo.explanation: The model closes two key feedback loops. First, as road rage incidents increase, learned behavior rises, which further increases new incidents—a reinforcing loop. Second, traffic congestion increases both frustration and perceived provocation, which raise stress and new incidents, feeding back into learned behavior. This structure captures how social normalization and situational stressors reinforce road rage. The model is kept simple by aggregating related factors and using constants for less dynamic variables.
supportingInfo.title: Feedback Loops Driving Road Rage Incidents

testParams.name: include a minimum number of feedback loops and a minimum number of variables for American Revolution
testParams.prompt: Using your knowledge of how the American Revolution started and the additional information I have given you, please give me a feedback-based explanation for how the American Revolution came about. Your response must include at least 6 feedback loops and at least 8 variables.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how the American Revolution started. I'd like to know what caused hostilities to break out.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
The American Revolution was caused by a number of factors, including:
Taxation
The British imposed new taxes on the colonies to raise money, such as the Stamp Act of 1765, which taxed legal documents, newspapers, and playing cards. The colonists were angry because they had no representatives in Parliament.
The Boston Massacre
In 1770, British soldiers fired on a crowd of colonists in Boston, killing five people. The massacre intensified anti-British sentiment and became a propaganda tool for the colonists.
The Boston Tea Party
The Boston Tea Party was a major act of defiance against British rule. It showed that Americans would not tolerate tyranny and taxation.
The Intolerable Acts
The British government passed harsh laws that the colonists called the Intolerable Acts. One of the acts closed the port of Boston until the colonists paid for the tea they had ruined.
The French and Indian War
The British wanted the colonies to repay them for their defense during the French and Indian War (1754–63).
Colonial identity
The colonists developed a stronger sense of American identity

supportingInfo.explanation: This model captures the complex interplay of British policies, colonial reactions, and key events leading to the American Revolution. Six feedback loops are present: (1) British war debt increases taxation, which increases grievances, which increase demands and possibly concessions, affecting grievances again; (2) Grievances increase colonial identity, which amplifies the impact of the Boston Tea Party, leading to harsher British acts, which further increase grievances; (3) Grievances increase military presence, which increases the chance and impact of violent incidents like the Boston Massacre, which amplifies propaganda, further increasing grievances; (4) Propaganda and key events reinforce each other, amplifying the cycle of grievance and identity; (5) Grievances drive both demands for representation and British concessions, both of which can resolve grievances, forming balancing loops; (6) Taxation pressure, driven by war debt, both increases grievances and enables debt repayment, which can reduce future taxation pressure, forming a balancing loop. These loops reflect both reinforcing and balancing archetypes, showing how escalating tensions and failed resolutions led to open hostilities.
supportingInfo.title: Feedback Loops Driving American Revolution Hostilities

testParams.prompt: Using your knowledge of how road rage happens and the additional information I have given you, please give me a feedback-based explanation for how road rage incidents might change in the future. Your response must include at least 6 feedback loops and at least 8 variables.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how road rage happens. I'd like to know what causes road rage in society.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
Road rage, defined as aggressive driving behavior caused by anger and frustration, can be triggered by various factors: 
Psychological Factors: 
Stress and Anxiety:
High stress levels can make drivers more irritable and prone to aggressive reactions. 
Personality Traits:
Individuals with impulsive, hostile, or competitive personalities may be more likely to engage in road rage. 
Frustration:
Feeling frustrated or blocked by other drivers can lead to anger and aggression. 
Situational Factors: 
Traffic Congestion:
Heavy traffic, delays, and stop-and-go conditions can increase stress and impatience. 
Perceived Provocations:
Being cut off, tailgated, or honked at can provoke anger and retaliatory behavior. 
Impatience:
Drivers who are running late or have a low tolerance for delays may become aggressive. 
Environmental Factors: 
Road Design:
Poor road design, such as narrow lanes or confusing intersections, can contribute to traffic congestion and frustration. 
Weather Conditions:
Adverse weather conditions, such as heavy rain or snow, can increase stress and make driving more challenging. 
Other Factors: 
Learned Behavior: Observing aggressive driving behavior from others can normalize it and increase the likelihood of engaging in road rage. 
Lack of Sleep: Fatigue can impair judgment and make drivers more susceptible to anger. 
Distracted Driving: Using a phone, texting, or eating while driving can increase the risk of accidents and provoke anger.

supportingInfo.explanation: This model closes multiple feedback loops by connecting road rage incidents to stress, frustration, impatience, learned behavior, traffic congestion, and perceived provocations. For example, more road rage incidents increase stress, which increases new incidents—a reinforcing loop. Similarly, incidents increase congestion, which increases frustration and impatience, further fueling new incidents. Learned behavior and perceived provocations are also reinforced by the prevalence of incidents, creating additional reinforcing loops. Distracted driving and lack of sleep act as amplifiers, feeding into provocations and stress. The model includes at least six feedback loops: (1) Road Rage Incidents → Stress Level → New Incidents → Road Rage Incidents; (2) Road Rage Incidents → Frustration Level → New Incidents → Road Rage Incidents; (3) Road Rage Incidents → Impatience Level → New Incidents → Road Rage Incidents; (4) Road Rage Incidents → Traffic Congestion → Stress/Frustration/Impatience → New Incidents → Road Rage Incidents; (5) Road Rage Incidents → Learned Behavior → New Incidents → Road Rage Incidents; (6) Road Rage Incidents → Perceived Provocations → New Incidents → Road Rage Incidents. These loops illustrate how road rage can escalate in society through reinforcing feedback.
supportingInfo.title: Multiple Feedback Loops Drive Road Rage

The British imposed new taxes on the colonies to raise money, such as the Stamp Act of 1765, which taxed legal documents, newspapers, and playing cards. The colonists were angry because they had no representatives in Parliament.
The Boston Massacre
In 1770, British soldiers fired on a crowd of colonists in Boston, killing five people. The massacre intensified anti-British sentiment and became a propaganda tool for the colonists.
The Boston Tea Party
The Boston Tea Party was a major act of defiance against British rule. It showed that Americans would not tolerate tyranny and taxation.
The Intolerable Acts
The British government passed harsh laws that the colonists called the Intolerable Acts. One of the acts closed the port of Boston until the colonists paid for the tea they had ruined.
The French and Indian War
The British wanted the colonies to repay them for their defense during the French and Indian War (1754–63).
Colonial identity
The colonists developed a stronger sense of American identity

supportingInfo.explanation: This model captures three main reinforcing feedback loops and one balancing loop. The first reinforcing loop is: British taxation increases colonial resentment, which increases protest actions, which leads to harsher Intolerable Acts, which further increases resentment. The second reinforcing loop is: protest actions increase British military presence, which increases resentment, leading to more protest. The third reinforcing loop is: colonial resentment strengthens colonial identity, which can further fuel protest actions. The balancing loop is: as colonial identity grows, it can channel and organize resentment, potentially reducing raw resentment. These loops reflect the escalation of hostilities and the emergence of a distinct American identity, both of which contributed to the outbreak of the Revolution.
supportingInfo.title: Feedback Loops Driving American Revolutionary Hostilities

testParams.prompt: Using your knowledge of how road rage happens and the additional information I have given you, please give me a feedback-based explanation for how road rage incidents might change in the future. Your response must include no more than 4 feedback loops and at least 5 variables.

additionalParameters.problemStatement: I am trying to understand how road rage happens. I'd like to know what causes road rage in society.
additionalParameters.backgroundKnowledge:
Road rage, defined as aggressive driving behavior caused by anger and frustration, can be triggered by various factors: 
Psychological Factors: 
Stress and Anxiety:
High stress levels can make drivers more irritable and prone to aggressive reactions. 
Personality Traits:
Individuals with impulsive, hostile, or competitive personalities may be more likely to engage in road rage. 
Frustration:
Feeling frustrated or blocked by other drivers can lead to anger and aggression. 
Situational Factors: 
Traffic Congestion:
Heavy traffic, delays, and stop-and-go conditions can increase stress and impatience. 
Perceived Provocations:
Being cut off, tailgated, or honked at can provoke anger and retaliatory behavior. 
Impatience:
Drivers who are running late or have a low tolerance for delays may become aggressive. 
Environmental Factors: 
Road Design:
Poor road design, such as narrow lanes or confusing intersections, can contribute to traffic congestion and frustration. 
Weather Conditions:
Adverse weather conditions, such as heavy rain or snow, can increase stress and make driving more challenging. 
Other Factors: 
Learned Behavior: Observing aggressive driving behavior from others can normalize it and increase the likelihood of engaging in road rage. 
Lack of Sleep: Fatigue can impair judgment and make drivers more susceptible to anger. 
Distracted Driving: Using a phone, texting, or eating while driving can increase the risk of accidents and provoke anger.

supportingInfo.explanation: This model closes several feedback loops implied by the background information. First, as road rage incidents increase, they worsen traffic congestion, which in turn raises stress and frustration, leading to even more incidents—a reinforcing loop. Second, more incidents normalize aggressive driving (learned behavior), which further increases new incidents—another reinforcing loop. Third, more incidents heighten perceived provocations, which increases frustration and thus new incidents—a third reinforcing loop. Finally, stress increases distracted driving, which also feeds into new incidents, creating a fourth reinforcing loop. These loops capture the escalation and self-reinforcing nature of road rage in society.
supportingInfo.title: Feedback Loops Driving Road Rage Escalation
